thread.title: The Quickest Way to Remove Weights After Heavy Deadlifts
thread.title_full: The Quickest Way to Remove Weights After Heavy Deadlifts

author: Stephanie Lee on Vitals, shared by Andy Orin to Lifehacker
title: The Quickest Way to Remove Weights After Heavy Deadlifts
text:
Go to permalink 
Imagine that you’ve just completed sets of heavy deadlifts . You’re tired, but now that you’re done you have to be a good gym-goer and take those weight plates off the barbell. Well, instead of trying to remove every plate individually, Omar Isuf shows you this super easy way to unload the weights efficiently and safely. Why Deadlifts Are Worth the Hype, and How to Do Them Safely Why Deadlifts Are Worth the Hype, and How to Do Them Safely Why Deadlifts Are Worth the Hype, and How to Do… Deadlifts: you either love ‘em or are afraid of ‘em. To the casual eye, they look like a great way… Read more Read more 
The solution is super simple: take a 5 or 10-pound plate, place it on the ground on one side of the barbell, and roll the plates over it. The small plate props up the barbell, allowing you to easily slide each plate off, instead of lifting the barbell off the ground and holding it while also stripping off a plate. Then once you’ve got one side done, the other side is a breeze. I mean, you still have to put the weights away, but still...! Advertisement Advertisement 
This method is great for people who have to remove more than two 45-pound plates on each side. I know that after doing really heavy deadlifts myself I’m not a fan of taking off all the plates afterward, but it’s something I have to do anyway. Since learning this method, I’ve had an easier time and wondered where the hell it has been all my life.
